The valence state and size of copper species play a critical role in the conversion of syngas to higher alcohols. In this study, CuAl binary catalysts with tunable Cu+-Cu0 ratios and broad size distributions were successfully synthesized by adjusting the heat-treatment pressure of complete liquid-phase method, and their performance in CO hydrogenation was evaluated. The characterization results demonstrated that increasing heat-treatment pressure led to a general increase in both the Cu species size and the Cu⁺/(Cu⁺+Cu0) ratio. Additionally, heat-treated under high pressure significantly enhanced the interaction between the Cu and Al components, promoted the formation of oxygen vacancies on AlOOH, and facilitated electron transfer. Notably, the oxygen vacancy content exhibited a linear correlation with the Cu+/(Cu++Cu0) ratio. The catalytic performance revealed a synergistic effect between the valence state and size of copper species in promoting higher alcohol synthesis. The percentage of C2+OH increased with the rise in Cu+/(Cu++Cu0) ratio and the size of Cu0 and Cu2O. Among the catalysts, C-4 exhibited the largest Cu0 and Cu2O sizes and the highest Cu⁺/(Cu⁺+Cu0) ratio, achieving the highest proportion of higher alcohols (53.52 %). In-situ DRIFTS experiments also confirmed the synergistic effect of both factors. Larger Cu particles facilitated the dissociative adsorption of CO, while Cu⁺ sites favored the non-dissociative adsorption of CO. This work significantly expands the understanding of the role of Cu+-Cu0 ratios and larger copper species in syngas conversion, offering valuable insights for the design of Cu-based catalysts with a high selectivity toward C2+OH. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CuAl binary catalyst Heat-treated under high pressure Syngas Higher alcohols Synergistic effect Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The global issues of energy shortage and environmental degradation are becoming increasingly severe, highlighting the urgent need for eco-friendly resource utilization methods. Coal, with its abundant reserves and low cost, will continue to play a significant role in the future energy consumption structure [1]. Higher alcohols (C2+OH) serve as critical intermediates in high value-added chemicals, such as pharmaceuticals, cosmetics, and polyesters [2,3]. Additionally, they represent essential chemicals with high octane ratings, capable of functioning not only as fuel additives but also as direct substitutes for traditional liquid fuels [4,5]. Gasifying coal to produce synthesis gas (CO/H2) and subsequently catalyzing it to obtain higher alcohols (C2+OH) enables clean and efficient coal utilization, thereby reducing NO x and CO2 emissions. Currently, the main catalyst systems for producing higher alcohols from syngas include Rh-based catalysts, Mo-based catalysts, modified Fischer-Tropsch synthesis catalysts, and modified methanol synthesis catalysts [6]. Although Rh-based catalysts exhibit high selectivity for higher alcohols, their expensive cost precludes large-scale industrialization [7–9]. Mo-based catalysts require harsh reaction conditions [10]. While modified F-T synthesis catalysts also demonstrate high selectivity for higher alcohols, they produce a complex mixture with numerous hydrocarbons, making separation challenging [11]. In contrast, modified methanol synthesis catalysts, due to their low cost and mild reaction conditions, have become the focal point of research for producing higher alcohols from synthesis gas [12]. It is well known that Cu-based catalysts are common methanol synthesis catalysts, yielding products with high methanol selectivity but low C2+OH selectivity. Therefore, increasing the selectivity for C2+OH over Cu-based catalysts remains a significant challenge for many researchers. The synthesis of higher alcohols from syngas is a process that relies on two distinct functional active sites. One site is responsible for carbon chain growth through CO dissociation and C-C coupling, while the other facilitates alcohol formation via non-dissociative CO adsorption and the insertion of CO/CHO [13]. This necessitates that the catalyst possesses bifunctional active sites capable of both dissociative and non-dissociative CO adsorption. The Cu-based catalysts have two active sites: Cu0 and Cu⁺ sites. Currently, the roles of them in the process of synthesizing higher alcohols remain a topic of controversy. According to Yang et al. [14], Cu+ sites had a strong affinity for CO adsorption, and an abundance of Cu⁺ components could enhance CO conversion significantly. Yu et al. [15] discovered that adjusting the number of Cu⁺ species in the catalyst markedly impacted the selectivity for higher alcohols. However, Liu et al. [16] suggested that the Cu0-Cu⁺ synergy acted as the site for both dissociative adsorption of H2 and non-dissociative adsorption of CO, with AlOOH promoting dissociative adsorption of CO. In their subsequent research, they found that larger Cu particles also facilitated dissociative adsorption of CO and the formation of Cu-ZnO interfaces promoted carbon chain growth and the production of higher alcohols [17]. This demonstrated the significant impact of Cu species size on the product distribution of the Cu-based catalyst. Sharma et al. [18] observed a linear correlation between Cu size and methanol formation rate, stating that smaller Cu particles showed a higher methanol production rate due to their larger specific surface area and high dispersion. Conversely, Karelovic et al. [19] contended that catalysts with larger size Cu0 and ZnO particles formed new active sites, consequently leading to higher methanol selectivity. This highlighted the complex relationship between the size of copper species and catalytic performance, as both large and small copper species can influence reaction mechanisms and product selectivity. Therefore, regulating the valence state and the size of Cu species is essential for enhancing the selectivity for C2+OH. In our previous work, the CuZnAl slurry catalyst prepared by complete liquid-phase method without alkali or F-T elements demonstrated excellent selectivity for higher alcohols [20]. The primary innovation of complete liquid-phase method lied in the direct preparation of the catalyst as a slurry from the solution, eliminating the traditional drying and calcination processes. Gu et al. [21] regulated the ratio of Cu0/Cu+ by controlling the relative amounts of gel and solution during the two-step hydrolysis process of the CuZnAl catalyst, discovering that high ethanol selectivity in the alcohol product was achieved within a specific Cu0/(Cu0+Cu+) ratio range of 0.277–0.358. Tian et al. [22] effectively modulated the oxygen vacancy content by adding Ga, which in turn adjusted the Cu0/Cu⁺ ratio on the CuZn binary catalyst surface, and resulting in outstanding catalytic performance. The fractions of ethanol and C2+OH reached 60.22 % and 71.90 %, respectively. Liu et al. [23] compared binary catalysts (CuZn, ZnAl, CuAl) with ternary CuZnAl catalysts, and the results showed that ethanol dominated the alcohol products of the CuZnAl, CuZn and ZnAl catalysts, while the alcohol products of the CuAl catalyst were primarily methanol. They concluded that Znδ+ played a significant role in the formation of higher alcohols, though it was undeniable that the CuAl binary catalysts also possessed the capability to synthesize higher alcohols. Deng et al. [24] prepared CuZnAl ternary catalysts by complete liquid-phase method under higher heat-treatment pressure and found the formation of Cu-Al spinel species, which could effectively regulate the content of Cu+ on the catalyst surface and promote the selectivity of higher alcohols. Moreover, we synthesized Cu nanoparticles with wide size distributions by varying the Cu/Al molar ratio of Cu-Al spinel catalysts, and the results showed that catalysts with large-sized Cu nanoparticles favored the generation of higher alcohols, and catalysts with small-sized Cu nanoparticles favored the generation of dimethyl ether [25]. This study builds on previous research by excluding the influence of Zn on the synthesis of higher alcohols, thereby allowing a focused investigation into Cu-Al binary catalysts. Specifically, the research aims to obtain catalysts with different Cu⁺- Cu0 ratios and Cu species sizes by altering the heat-treatment pressure of complete liquid-phase method. The primary objective is to explore the synergistic effect of the Cu⁺-Cu0 ratio and Cu species size on the product distribution during CO hydrogenation. This approach offers a novel perspective for understanding the structure-activity relationship of the essential active sites. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, liquid paraffin, ethanol and petroleum ether were obtained from Tianjin Kemiou Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., China. Aluminium isopropoxide was purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd., China. All chemical reagents were analytical grade and used without further purification. CO, H2, N2, Ar and He, with purities of 99.99 %, were provided by the Product of Taiyuan Fujiang Special Gas Co., Ltd., China. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The CuAl slurry catalysts were prepared by complete liquid-phase method. The catalyst composition was molar ratio Cu/Al = 1:2. Firstly, 40.9 g of aluminum isopropoxide [(C3H7O)3Al] was dissolved in 70 mL of ethanol and heated to 75 °C under stirring for 1 h to form aluminum solution. Subsequently, an alcoholic solution of copper nitrate (24.2 g of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O dissolved in 35 mL of ethanol) was pumped into above aluminum solution and continued to be refluxed and stirred for 4 h. The mixture was then heated to 85 °C, 150 mL of distilled water was added, and the open flask hydrolysis was continued until a blue gel formed. After aging at 25 °C for 10 days, the catalyst precursor was obtained. The aged catalyst precursor was uniformly dispersed in 200 mL of liquid paraffin and placed in a 500 mL slurry reactor. Under a flowing N2 atmosphere, the pressure was slowly increased to the specified pressure, and the temperature was raised from room temperature to 280 °C at a rate of 1 °C/min. The catalysts were heat-treated for 8 h under pressures of atmospheric, 1.0, 2.0, 3.0, and 4.0 MPa, named as C-0, C-1, C-2, C-3, and C-4, respectively. 2.3 Catalyst characterization Prior to characterization, all catalysts were extracted with petroleum ether for 4 days to eliminate the effect of residual liquid paraffin. After extraction, solid powder catalysts were obtained by natural drying and then characterized. The XRD patterns were recorded using a Rigaku DX-2700 X-ray diffractometer, using Cu-targeted Kα-rays as the radiation source, which were scanned at a rate of 5°/min over a range of 5°∼85° for 2θ. The N2 absorption-desorption was performed on a Micromeritics Quanta chrome equipment using N2 as adsorbate at −196 °C. 0.2 g of catalyst was degassed and pretreated at 200 °C for 4.5 h to remove water and impurities. The specific surface area was calculated by the BET method, and the pore volume and pore size were calculated by the BJH method. H2-TPR characterization was used to analyze the reduction properties of the catalysts, which was tested using a TP-5080 chemisorption apparatus by Tianjin Xianquan Company. 0.05 g of catalyst was purged at 150 °C under N2 atmosphere for 30 min, and when the temperature was cooled down to 50 °C, the N2 was switched to 5 % H2 /N2 reducing gas (30 mL/min). The reduction test was carried out by ramping up the temperature to 810 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min, and the hydrogen depletion signals of the catalysts were recorded by using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). TEM characterization was determined on a Tecnai G2 F20 transmission electron microscope with an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. Prior to testing, the catalysts were dispersed in ethanol, sonicated, and then the obtained supernatant was placed on a carbon coated Cu grid for observation. XPS was characterized on an AXIS SUPRA03030708 instrument with Al kα rays as the radiation source. The vacuum of the analysis chamber was 9.5 × 10−9 Pa and the operating voltage was 14.95 kV. All binding energies were corrected by the C1s peak at 284.8 eV. NH3/CO2-TPD-MS was used to detect the surface acidity and alkalinity of the catalysts, which was performed by a TP-5080 chemisorption apparatus by Tianjin Xianquan Company. Before the test, 100 mg of catalyst was loaded into a quartz tube and heated up to 280 °C in a stream of He gas and maintained for 30 min. After cooling down to 50 °C, the NH3/CO2 adsorption was switched for 30 min, and then it was purged with He for 60 min, and raised to 810 °C at 10 °C/min. The NH3/CO2 desorption amount was detected by a mass spectrometry detector (QIC-20). In-situ DRIFTS experiments were analyzed on a Bruker INVENIOS infrared spectrometer equipped with a MCT detector, with the catalysts placed in an in-situ cell equipped with a ZnSe window. Prior to each test, all catalysts were pretreated in Ar for 30 min before recording the background spectra, which were scanned 64 times with a resolution of 4 cm−1. Then, CO gas was introduced into the in-situ cell at 280 °C for 60 min and the CO adsorption spectra were recorded. Finally, the spectra were recorded every 2 min at room temperature. The in-situ surface reaction experiments were carried out in a syngas (H2/CO=2) atmosphere. 2.4 Catalytic evaluation The catalyst after heat-treatment under different pressure was evaluated in a 500 mL slurry reactor without pre-reduction. The solid holdup was 10 %. The specific reaction conditions included a syngas ratio of V(H2)/V(CO)=2/1, total flow rate of 150 mL/min, pressure maintained at 4.0 MPa, reaction temperature of 280 °C, and the reaction duration for 7 days. The reaction products were detected using a Hysin GC-950 gas chromatograph. All activity data were recorded after 24 h of reaction, once the catalyst performance had stabilized. The CO conversion and product selectivity were calculated by the following equations: (1) X C O = ∑ n i ( g ) + ∑ n i ( l ) n ( c o ) o u t + ∑ n i ( g ) + ∑ n i ( l ) × 100 % (2) S i = n i ( g ) + n i ( l ) ∑ n i ( g ) + ∑ n i ( l ) × 100 % Where X CO is the conversion rate of CO (C-mol%); S i is the selectivity of component i (C-mol%); i is all C-containing compounds other than CO in the products of the gas and liquid phases; n(CO)out is the amount of CO in the exit gas (mol); n i(g) is the number of moles of carbon atoms of component i in the exit gas (mol); and n i(l) is the number of moles of carbon atoms of component i in the liquid phase moles of component i carbon atoms in the liquid phase (mol). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance The CO hydrogenation performance of CuAl binary catalysts heat-treated under different pressure is tested at 280 °C and 4.0 MPa (H2/CO=2). Fig. 1 a and Fig. 1b presents the average product selectivity, the proportion of C2+OH/ROH, alcohol distribution and CO conversion for five catalysts over a 7-day period, respectively. As shown in Fig. 1a, with increasing heat-treatment pressure, the ROH selectivity of the CuAl binary catalysts shows a slight increase, maintaining at a range of 10–16 %. The proportion of higher alcohols (C2+OH/ROH) exhibits an overall upward trend, indicating that higher heat-treatment pressures favor the production of higher alcohols. This confirms that the CuAl binary catalyst, prepared by complete liquid-phase method, indeed has the capability to synthesize higher alcohols. CuAl catalysts reported by Hong et al. [25] predominantly produce dimethyl ether (DME) as the main product, with a selectivity of 37.26 %, and methanol accounted for 99 % of the alcohol distribution. Similarly, in the study by Zhu et al. [26], the selectivity of DME over the CuAl catalyst reaches 43.1 %. However, in this work, the selectivity of DME for all catalysts is very low. Moreover, compared to catalyst C-0 (CO2 selectivity: 64.36 %, HC selectivity: 23.72 %), the CO2 selectivity of the catalysts heat-treated under high pressure significantly decreases, while the HC selectivity increases markedly. This indicates that the catalysts heat-treated under high pressure can suppress CO2 formation and exhibit a stronger carbon chain growth capability. We will elaborate on the reasons for this phenomenon in the subsequent discussion. Furthermore, with the increase in heat-treatment pressure, the CO conversion significantly decreases. Catalyst C-0 shows the highest CO conversion at 51.96 %, but as the heat-treatment pressure increases to 4.0 MPa, the CO conversion drops sharply to 13.37 %. Fig. 1c and 1d record the stability of representative catalysts C-0 and C-4 over 168 h of activity evaluation. As shown in the figures, the CO conversion and the selectivity of various products remain stable, indicating that the structure of the catalyst is stable during the reaction. 3.2 XRD characterization The XRD patterns of different CuAl binary catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 . The catalyst C-0 exhibits a variety of valence states for copper species, including CuO, Cu2O, and Cu, with a very weak peak intensity for CuO. The existence of Cu2O and Cu is attributed to the reducing properties of hydrogen and alkyl radicals generated from the thermal cracking of inert medium, liquid paraffin, utilized in complete liquid-phase method [27]. However, when the heat-treatment pressure reaches 1.0 MPa, the characteristic diffraction peaks of CuO begin to further weaken. Subsequently, as the heat-treatment pressure further increases beyond 2.0 MPa, these peaks completely disappear. This observation suggests that heat-treatment under high pressure promotes the reduction of CuO. Additionally, aluminum species primarily exist in the form of AlOOH, which is a typical characteristic of catalyst prepared using complete liquid-phase method [28]. Notably, the diffraction peaks of the catalyst C-0 heat-treated under atmospheric pressure appear more diffuse, while those of the catalysts heat-treated under high pressure exhibit higher peak intensities and sharper peak shapes, indicating that higher heat-treatment pressure improves the crystallinity of the catalyst. High-resolution TEM image of the typical catalyst C-4 (see Fig. 5) reveals lattice spacings of 0.20 and 0.25 nm, corresponding to Cu0 (111) and Cu2O (111) crystal planes, respectively, which suggests that the catalysts are primarily exposed to these two crystal planes. Combined TEM and XRD characterization, the crystallite sizes of Cu0 and Cu2O are calculated from the full width at half maximum of Cu0 (111) and Cu2O (111) diffraction peak by means of the Scherrer's formula, respectively. As presented in Table 1 , with heat-treatment pressure increasing, both Cu0 and Cu2O crystallite sizes gradually increase, indicating that higher heat-treatment pressures favor the formation of larger Cu species. Liu et al. [17] propose that larger Cu species are conducive to the synthesis of higher alcohols. When the Cu species size increases from 11.8 nm to 49.2 nm, the C2+OH/ROH ratio significantly rises from 8.9 % to approximately 68.6 %, due to the larger Cu species facilitating the dissociation of C-O bonds, thereby forming the key intermediate CHₓ necessary for higher alcohols, which is in accordance with our results. Additionally, with increasing heat-treatment pressure, the decrease in CO conversion is also attributed to larger size of the Cu species. Literature indicates that smaller Cu species exhibit better dispersion and consequently higher CO conversion. Conversely, as the size of the Cu species increases, their dispersion decreases, leading to a reduction in CO conversion [29]. 3.3 N2 adsorption characterization Fig. 3 shows the N2 adsorption/desorption profiles and pore size distribution of the CuAl binary catalysts, respectively. As shown in Fig. 3a, the adsorption isotherms of all catalysts belong to type IV and exhibit distinct hysteresis loops, which are characteristic of mesoporous materials. However, the catalyst C-0 shows an H4-type hysteresis loop, indicating the presence of narrow columnar pores. In contrast, the catalysts heat-treated under high pressure exhibit H3-type hysteresis loops, suggesting the presence of slit-like pores. From the pore size distribution curves in Fig. 3b, the pore size of the catalyst C-0 appears to be concentrated at 3.8 nm, while for other catalysts after heat-treated under high pressure, the pore size is distributed at 17–31 nm, which is significantly larger than that of the catalyst C-0. This is due to the fact that as the heat-treatment pressure increases, the small pores of the catalyst collapse and the particles agglomerate, resulting in the appearance of more accumulation pores. Table 1 presents the textural parameters of the five catalysts. It can be observed that the catalysts heat-treated under high pressure exhibit higher specific surface area, pore volume, and pore diameter compared to the atmospheric pressure-treated catalyst C-0, which suggests that heat-treatment under high pressure can make the pore structure of the catalysts undergo significant changes. The literature reports that a larger pore volume provides sufficient space for carbon chain growth of the products, thereby facilitating the formation of long-chain compounds [30]. Additionally, a larger pore size not only allows reactants to reach active sites more rapidly but also enables quicker departure of the products. In this study, catalyst C-0 exhibits the lowest hydrocarbons selectivity and C2+OH/ROH, confirming that larger pore volume and pore size are more favorable for the formation of long-chain products. Therefore, it can be concluded that catalysts after heat-treated under high pressure promote the formation of higher alcohols. 3.4 FT-IR Fig. 4 presents the FT-IR spectra of the catalysts heat-treated under different pressure. The absorption peaks below 1000 cm−1 are characteristic of the stretching and bending vibrations of Al-O-Al [31]. The peak observed at 1070 cm−1 is attributed to the symmetric bending vibration of Al-O-H, while a shoulder at 1160 cm−1 corresponds to its asymmetric bending vibration. Additionally, the absorption peak at 3097 cm−1 is associated with the asymmetric stretching vibration of (Al) O-H and is a characteristic peak of the interlayer structural water in the AlOOH structure that participates in bonding interactions. The absorption peak at 3299 cm−1 corresponds to the symmetric stretching vibration of (Al) O-H. These characteristic absorption bands at 1070, 1160, 3097 and 3299 cm−1 reveal a rich presence of OH groups on the catalyst surface, further confirming that Al predominantly exists in the form of AlOOH, and the intensity of these absorption peaks is directly related to the crystallinity of AlOOH [32,33]. Notably, the catalysts heat-treated under high pressure display strong absorption peaks at these positions, indicating that the layered structure of AlOOH is preserved with high crystallinity in these catalysts. In contrast, the weaker intensity of these peaks for catalyst C-0 implies lower crystallinity, consistent with the results of the XRD analysis. Additionally, the absorption peak at 1382 cm−1 is attributed to the anti-symmetric stretching vibration of the N-O bond produced by the NO3 − ions in the nitrate, showing incomplete decomposition of nitrate during catalyst preparation [34]. Meanwhile, compared to the other four catalysts, the catalyst C-0 exhibits a new absorption peak at 3426 cm−1, corresponding to the asymmetric vibration of OH in H2O molecules, as well as a stronger absorption peak at 1627 cm−1, indicative of the symmetric vibration of OH in H2O molecules. This suggests a higher content of free water in the catalyst C-0, indicating that it is more hydrophilic compared to the catalysts after heat-treated under high pressure. 3.5 TEM The TEM images of catalysts heat-treated under different pressure are shown in Fig. 5 . It is evident that the catalyst C-0 displays irregular oxide flakes (gray regions) with Cu particles (dark spheres) encapsulated within. As the heat-treatment pressure increases, as seen in Fig. 5(b-e), the morphology of the catalysts evolves, exhibiting increasingly distinct rod-like structures. Based on XRD characterization, these structures are attributed to well-crystallized AlOOH phases. Concurrently, Cu species are tightly bound to the surrounding Al components, with Cu effectively embedded among these Al species. Combined with FT-IR characterization, the formation of such structure may be due to the intact AlOOH lamellar structure after heat-treated under high pressure, which facilitates the embedding of Cu into AlOOH. At the same time, larger Cu particles are observed in the catalyst C-4, indicating that as the heat-treatment pressure increases, Cu species have undergone growth, which in accordance with the XRD results. In the catalyst C-0, the Cu particles are encapsulated, resulting in the Cu0 and Cu⁺ active sites being covered by an AlOOH layer. Consequently, AlOOH becomes the initial interface that syngas contacts. FT-IR characterization results show that the catalyst C-0 is more hydrophilic. Due to its strong water adsorption properties, the catalyst C-0 facilitates the water-gas shift reaction (CO + H2O → CO2 + H2), leading to the highest CO2 selectivity of 64.36 %. In contrast, when the catalyst heat-treated under high pressure, the Cu species become embedded on the AlOOH surface, with the Cu0-Cu+-AlOOH ternary active sites directly exposed to the reactants, which significantly enhances the synthesis of CH x *, the key intermediate for higher alcohols and hydrocarbon. 3.6 H2-TPR characterization H2-TPR profiles of CuAl binary catalysts with different heat-treatment pressure are displayed in Fig. 6 . The negative peaks appeared at about 450 °C for all catalysts are due to the decomposition of the residual liquid paraffin. Catalysts C-0 and C-1 exhibit a single reduction peak within the temperature range of 203–435 °C. When the heat-treatment pressure is increased to ≥2.0 MPa, two reduction peaks appear. Based on the XRD characterization results, the reduction peak corresponding to CuO in catalysts C-0 and C-1 may be overshadowed due to its extremely low content [35]. Consequently, the observed peaks are primarily attributed to two types of reducible Cu2O. The low-temperature reduction peak, named α (203–366 °C), is assigned to the reduction of Cu2O with different crystallite sizes, while the medium-temperature reduction peak, labeled β (373–435 °C), is attributed to the reduction of Cu2O that interacts strongly with Al species. Notably, as the heat-treatment pressure increases, the center of the α peak gradually shifts toward higher temperatures. Gao et al. [36] report that larger crystallite sizes of Cu species lead to an increase in reduction temperature. XRD analysis confirms that the increase in heat-treated pressure leads to the growth of Cu2O crystallite sizes, making them more difficult to be reduced. Similarly, the center of the β peak also gradually shifts towards higher temperatures, further indicating that high pressure heat-treatment enhances the interaction between Cu and Al. Additionally, the reduction peak area of the catalyst C-2 is the smallest, indicating the lowest amount of reducible Cu2O in this sample. This observation aligns with the XRD results, where the diffraction peak intensity of Cu2O is also the weakest. 3.7 XPS characterization The chemical states and compositions of the surface elements of each catalyst are analyzed using XPS. As shown in Fig. 7 a, the binding energy peaks near 932.2 and 952.2 eV are attributed to Cu 2p 3/2 and Cu 2p 1/2, respectively. No significant shake-up peaks between 940–945 eV are detected in all catalysts, indicating that the Cu species on the catalyst surface primarily exist as low-valent copper (Cu⁺ and Cu0), which is consistent with XRD results. Moreover, the Al 2p spectra (Fig. 7b) exhibit a peak near 74.5 eV, which is ascribed to AlOOH [37] based on XRD and FT-IR results. An interference peak at 77.0 eV is related to Cu 3p [27]. Notably, as the heat-treatment pressure increases, the Cu 2p signal shifts towards higher binding energy, while the Al 2p signal exhibits an opposite shift. This confirms that heat-treated under high pressure enhances the interaction between the Cu-Al binary components, consistent with TPR characterization results. To distinguish between Cu+ and Cu0 on the catalyst surface, Fig. 8 a presents the Cu LMM Auger spectra of the catalysts, which can be deconvoluted into two peaks. The peak around 919.5 and 917.0 eV corresponds to Cu0 and Cu+, respectively, showing the coexistence of Cu0 and Cu+. As shown in Table 2 , the overall Cu⁺/(Cu⁺+Cu0) ratio gradually increases with increasing heat-treatment pressure, demonstrating that heat-treatment under high pressure can effectively regulate Cu⁺/(Cu⁺+Cu0) ratio of the catalyst surface. The elemental content on the catalyst surface is listed in Table 2. It can be seen that a significant decrease in the content of Cu on the catalyst surface after heat-treated under high pressure, while the change in content of Al is insignificant. n(Cu)/n(Al) on the catalyst surface is much lower than the feeding ratio [n(Cu):n(Al)=1:2], because the lattice energy of Al is greater than that of Cu, and the heat-treatment under high pressure facilitates the enrichment of Al on the catalyst surface. Meanwhile, the C content of the C-0 catalyst, heat-treated under atmospheric pressure, is as high as 42.32 %. However, after heat-treated under high pressure, the C content significantly decreases, due to the promotion of liquid paraffin decomposition by heat-treatment under high pressure, thereby preventing carbon deposition. Moreover, after heat-treatment under high pressure, the catalyst surface exhibits a high oxygen content. The O 1s spectra of the catalysts are presented in the Fig. 8b. Each spectrum can be deconvoluted into the following three peaks: (1) ∼530.2 eV, attributed to oxygen in lattice structure Al-O-Al (OL); (2) ∼531.5 eV, associated with the formation of surface oxygen vacancies (OV) on the AlOOH surface [38]; (3) ∼532.4 eV, corresponding to chemisorbed oxygen species (OC). The relative content of oxygen vacancies (OV (%)) can be calculated by fitting the area to OL, OV and OC using the following equation: OV (%) = A OV/(A OL+A OV+A OC). As shown in Table 2, the oxygen vacancy content in catalysts heat-treated under high pressure is higher than that in catalyst C-0, with an overall increasing trend. This is mainly attributed to the fact that CuAl binary catalysts heat-treated under high pressure are favored to create more defects, which leads to the formation of oxygen vacancies. Additionally, the generation of oxygen vacancies leads to the appearance of electron-rich unsaturated Al, which causes a shift in the Al 2p binding energy towards a lower direction [38]. Notably, A OV/(A OL+A OV+A OC) shows almost linear positive correlations with Cu+/(Cu++Cu0) ratio, as shown in Fig. 9 . Tian et al. [22] report that the presence of oxygen vacancies can induce electrons to overcome the Schottky barrier, enhancing the interaction between active metals and adjusting the Cu⁺/ Cu0 ratio on the catalyst surface. In other words, heat-treatment under high pressure increases the number of oxygen vacancies on the surface of AlOOH. These vacancies play a crucial role in enhancing the interaction between the Cu-Al binary components, facilitating electron transfer. As a result, Cu0 loses electrons, promoting the formation of more Cu⁺ on the catalyst surface. 3.8 NH3/CO2-TPD-MS analysis The formation of higher alcohols from syngas involves two crucial steps: carbon chain growth and alcohol formation, which are significantly influenced by the acidity and basicity of the catalyst surface [6,13,39–42]. To evaluate these properties, NH3/CO2-TPD-MS analysis are performed. As shown in Fig. 10 a, all catalysts display a single NH3 desorption peak around 530 °C, corresponding to medium-strength acid sites on the catalyst surface, with no weak acid sites detected. The literature indicates that weak acid sites are pivotal in the dehydration of methanol to produce DME [43], which accounts for the low DME selectivity observed across all catalysts. Li et al. [44] propose that the Cu/Al2O3 catalyst with medium-strength acidity at 500 °C is more conducive to carbon chain growth of alcohol products compared to the Cu/SiO2 catalyst, which exhibits weaker acidity at 270 °C. Meanwhile, Xu et al. [45] associate medium-strong acid sites with the formation of hydrocarbon. In this study, the peak temperature for medium-strength acid sites remains similar for all catalysts, but the peak areas vary significantly, indicating that comparable acid strength but differing densities of medium-strength acid sites among the catalysts. As shown in Table 3 , the catalyst C-0 possesses a significantly lower density of medium-strength acid sites compared to the other four catalysts. This suggests that heat-treated under high pressure is an effective method to increase the density of medium-strength acid sites in catalysts. Combined with the activity evaluation results, it is evident that a higher density of medium-strength acid sites is essential for CO activation and C-C bond formation, ultimately promoting the formation of hydrocarbons and higher alcohols. Fig. 10b shows the CO2-TPD-MS profiles of different catalysts. All catalysts display a broad desorption peak in the range of 300–500 °C, accompanied by a shoulder peak, corresponding to medium-strength basic sites. The density of basic sites of each catalyst is listed in Table 3. Compared to C-0, the catalyst heat-treated under high pressure show an increased density of medium-strength basic sites. Luk et al. [6] report that the synthesis of higher alcohols is related to the alkaline potential on the catalyst surface, and the alkaline environment is conducive to the insertion of CO. Similarly, Santos et al. [46] note that the basic sites stabilize surface intermediates, enhancing the formation of higher alcohols through CO insertion and base-catalyzed aldol condensation. Zhu et al. [41] highlight that the medium-strength basic sites facilitate the formation of higher alcohols. Combining these insights with the findings of this study, it can be inferred that the higher density of medium-strength basic sites in this study contributes to CO insertion and base-catalyzed aldol condensation, thereby playing a pivotal role in alcohols formation. According to the literature, the CO2 desorption peaks between 300 °C and 450 °C are associated with M-O pairs, where M represents a metal element, while peaks above 450 °C are related to coordinated unsaturated O2− [47–49]. Therefore, the CO2 desorption peak is deconvoluted into four distinct peaks, labeled as Peaks Ⅰ-Ⅳ. Peak Ⅰ is attributed to Cu-O pairs, Peak Ⅱ to Al-O pairs, Peak Ⅲ to strongly interacting Cu-O-Al pairs, and Peak Ⅳ to coordinated unsaturated O2− [50], which arise from the formation of oxygen vacancies. Thus, using the peak area in CO2-TPD to quantify the oxygen vacancy content is justified [51]. Table 3 presents the CO2 desorption area ratios of the four peaks, unveiling that the proportion of Peak Ⅳ increases progressively with higher heat-treatment pressure. This further confirms that heat-treatment under high pressure promotes the formation of oxygen vacancies. 3.9 Role of Cu⁺-Cu0 ratio and Cu species size A correlation between the size of Cu species and catalyst performance is plotted to elucidate the role of Cu species size. As depicted in Fig. 11 , an increase in the size of Cu0 from 21.3 nm to 39.5 nm and Cu2O from 17.5 nm to 25.1 nm results in a rapid rise in the C2+OH/ROH ratio from 39.02 % to 49.87 %. Further increases in the size of Cu species (Cu0 to 53.1 nm and Cu2O to 36.1 nm) lead to a slight increase in the C2+OH/ROH ratio, reaching 53.52 %. Moreover, the sizes of Cu0 and Cu2O exhibit a positive linear correlation with ROH selectivity but a negative correlation with CO conversion, indicating a trade-off between activity-selectivity. This reveals a challenge in balancing high CO conversion with high C2+OH/ROH and ROH selectivity. Additionally, as the size of Cu species increases, CO2 selectivity gradually decreases while hydrocarbon selectivity rises (see Fig. 11c and 11d). This suggests a competitive relationship: smaller Cu species favor CO2 generation, while larger Cu species facilitate the formation of long-chain hydrocarbons. This observation further confirm that the larger Cu species possess a stronger CO dissociation ability, promoting carbon chains growth. The correlation between Cu+/(Cu++Cu0) ratios and C2+OH/ROH is also explored in Fig. 12 . The proportion of C2+OH/ROH increases linearly with Cu+/(Cu++Cu0) ratio, uncovering that a higher abundance of Cu⁺ on the catalyst surface favors the formation of C2+OH. This effect is attributed to the electrophilic nature of Cu⁺ sites, which can polarize and activate C=O bonds, facilitating the insertion of CO*/CHO* into CH x * to form surface acyl species, followed by hydrogenation to produce C2+OH [23,52]. The detail mechanism will be further explained in the subsequent in-situ DRIFTS section. In conclusion, our findings suggest a synergistic effect between the valence state and size of Cu species, which plays a crucial role in the CO hydrogenation process for synthesizing higher alcohols over Cu-Al binary catalysts. 3.10 Reaction mechanism of C2+OH synthesis To gain deeper insights into the CO adsorption behavior of catalysts heat-treated under different pressures, C-0, C-1, and C-3 are chosen as representative catalysts for in-situ CO-DRIFT analysis. Initially, the catalysts are pre-adsorbed in a CO stream at 280 °C for 60 min, followed by flushing with an Ar stream at room temperature. As shown in Fig. 13 , all catalysts exhibit two distinct peaks at 2176 and 2116 cm−1. The intensities of two peaks decrease and eventually stabilize after flushing in the Ar stream. The peak at 2176 cm−1 is associated with gaseous CO adsorption, while the peak at 2116 cm−1 is related to linear CO adsorption on the copper site [53]. He et al. [54] report that CO adsorption by Cu0 and Cu2+ is usually weak and reversible, whereas the linear CO adsorption by Cu+ is more stable. Therefore, the peak at 2116 cm−1, which exhibits greater resistance to flushing, is attributed to the linear adsorption of CO on the Cu+ site. Moreover, Fig. 13d shows that after 9 min of Ar flushing, the intensity of (Cu+-CO) peak at 2116 cm−1 for catalysts C-1 and C-3 is significantly higher than that for catalyst C-0, due to a higher Cu+ content on the surface of the catalysts heat-treated under high pressure, consistent with XPS results. It is well known that linearly adsorbed CO facilitates non-dissociative CO adsorption, which is essential for CO/CHO insertion [55], a key step in the synthesizing higher alcohols from syngas. In addition, the series of peaks between 1960 to 1998 cm−1 are attributed to bridge CO adsorption on Cu0 [17,56,57]. Such bridged CO adsorption is more prone to dissociation to form key intermediates CH x * [58]. Additionally, after stabilization, the intensity of peaks in the range 1960 to 1998 cm−1 increases with higher heat-treatment pressure due to the growth in the size of copper species. Liu et al. [17] suggest that larger Cu particles enhance the probability of bridged CO adsorption, thereby providing a higher concentration of CH x intermediates, which can be confirmed in the subsequent intermediate reaction section. In summary, this study demonstrates that increasing heat-treatment pressure results in a larger size of Cu0, as well as a higher proportion of Cu+ on the catalyst surface. We propose a synergistic interaction between Cu⁺ sites and larger size copper species. Specifically, the enhanced linear adsorption of CO on Cu⁺ sites increases the probability of CO/CHO insertion. At the same time, larger Cu sizes facilitate an increase in CO bridge adsorption and its subsequent dissociation to form CH x , thereby promoting carbon chain growth and the formation of higher alcohols. To investigate the surface intermediates and possible reaction pathways of CO hydrogenation to C2+OH, in-situ DRIFTS of CO+H2 experiment is performed on representative catalyst C-0, C-1, and C-3. At 280 °C and 0.1 MPa, a syngas mixture (H2/CO=2) is introduced, and the spectra of the flow are recorded over 30 min period, as shown in the Fig. 14 and Table 4 . The peaks at 3034 and 1574 cm−1 are attributed to the C-H and C-O bonds of the CHO* intermediate formed by the hydrogenation of activated CO* [59]. The peak at 3014 cm−1 is ascribed to the saturated C-H bond in CH4 [59,60]. And the absorption peaks at 2924,1470 and 1454 cm−1 are related to the unsaturated C-H bond in CH x * [22,59,60], which are considered to be a key intermediate in the synthesis of C2+OH on Cu-based catalysts, and are generated by the dissociation of bridge-adsorbed CO [61]. Zuo et al. [62] utilize DFT calculations to demonstrate that the formation of CH3 intermediate plays a crucial role in synthesizing higher alcohols through subsequent CO insertion. The generation of CH x * and CH4 confirms the dissociation of C-O bonds on the catalyst surface. Moreover, the signal at 1658 cm−1 is associated to the ketene species CH2CO* [17,63], while those at 2855 and 1434 cm−1 correspond to the aldehyde species CH3CHO* [17,60]. Additionally, the peaks at 2950 and 2886 cm−1 are attributed to ethoxy species CH3CH2O* [17,59,60]. The presence of these intermediates verifies that C-C coupling occurs via the CO/CHO* insertion mechanism. In this system, the ketones species are formed by the insertion of CO* into CH x * (CH x * + CO* → CH x CO*), while aldehyde species are derived from the coupling of CH x * and CH n O* (CH x * + CH n O* → CH x CH n O*). Furthermore, the bands at 1556 and 1393 cm−1 are assigned to the antisymmetric ν as(OCO) and ν s(OCO) coming from formate species (HCOO*) [22,64], likely produced via the hydrogenation of gaseous CO2. The bands corresponding to gaseous CO2, detected at 2359 and 2327 cm−1 [60], are primarily attributed to the water-gas shift reaction (CO + H2O → CO2 + H2). Fig. 15 a and 15b display a comparison of IR signal of catalysts with different heat-treatment pressures for 5 min. The intensity of the characteristic CH x * intermediates peak at 2924 cm−1 increases significantly with rising pressure. Combined with in-situ CO-DRIFT characterization, we believe that higher heat-treatment pressures, which lead to the formation of larger copper species, enhance the catalyst's ability to dissociate CO. This results in a marked increase in the coverage of CH x * intermediates, facilitating subsequent coupling hydrogenation to hydrocarbons and CO/CHO insertion to alcohols. Additionally, the peaks at 2855 and 1434 cm−1, associated with the aldehyde intermediates CH x CH n O*, exhibit increased intensities after heat-treatment at high pressure. This is attributed to a higher proportion of Cu+ species on the catalyst surface, supporting the conclusion that Cu+ species favors the insertion of CHO*. Zhang et al. [65] report that CHO insertion into CH3 is more favorable for generating CH3CHO than CO insertion into CH3 to form CH3CO. This likely explains why changes in ketene intermediates are less pronounced. Moreover, as heat-treatment pressure increases, the intensity of the CHO* peak at 3034 cm−1 and the CH3O* peak at 1417cm−1 rises simultaneously [59], implying that CHO* species are less prone to direct hydrogenation to CH3O*, and further hydrogenation to CH3OH is also limited. In summary, increasing heat-treatment pressure is highly effective in promoting the formation of larger copper species and increasing the proportion of Cu⁺ on the catalyst surface. This synergy enhances the coverage of C2+OH precursors (CH x CH n O*) and key intermediates CH x *, while inhibiting the direct hydrogenation of CH3O* to CH3OH, thereby significantly elevates the C2+OH/ROH ratio. Based on the in-situ DRIFTS results, we propose the following plausible pathway for the synthesis of higher alcohols over CuAl binary catalysts (see Fig. 16 ): (1) The non-dissociative CO adsorbed on the Cu+ site is first hydrogenated to form CHO*. Meanwhile, bridge adsorbed CO on larger copper species undergoes C-O bond cleavage, resulting in the formation of CH x * intermediates. These intermediates then coupled with each other to form aldehydes CH x CHO*, which can be further coupled or hydrogenated to produce higher alcohols. (2) The non-dissociative CO adsorbed on the Cu+ site is directly inserted into CH x * to generate the enone CH x CO*, which can subsequently undergo coupling or hydrogenation to generate higher alcohols. 4 Conclusions To regulate two critical factors, the valence state and size of Cu species, in the synthesis of higher alcohols from CO hydrogenation over CuAl binary catalysts, we optimized the heat-treatment pressure during complete liquid-phase method, successfully preparing catalysts with varying Cu+/(Cu++Cu0) ratios and a broad distributions of Cu species sizes. The results demonstrated that high pressure heat-treatment significantly enhanced the interaction between the Cu and Al components, promoted oxygen vacancy formation and facilitated electron transfer, with oxygen vacancies showing a linear correlation with Cu+/(Cu++Cu0) ratio. Notably, a synergistic effect between larger Cu species and a higher Cu+/(Cu++Cu0) ratio achieved the highest C2+OH percentage (53.52 %), with C2+OH percentage increased linearly with Cu+/(Cu++Cu0) ratio. Furthermore, In-situ DRIFTS experiments revealed that larger Cu particles promoted bridged CO adsorption, facilitating CO dissociation to form CH x * intermediates. Meanwhile, Cu+ active sites facilitated the non-dissociative CO adsorption, enhancing the insertion of CO/CHO into CH x * intermediates and promoting higher alcohols production. Additionally, the heat-treatment conditions also influenced by-product distribution, with high pressure treated catalyst exhibiting lower CO2 selectivity and higher hydrocarbon selectivity, indicating an improved capability for carbon chain growth under such conditions. Thus, future efforts should focus on further enhancing non-dissociative CO adsorption to promote the insertion of more CO/CHO intermediates, thereby facilitating alcohol formation. Our findings advance the understanding of the interplay between Cu+/(Cu++Cu0) ratios and Cu species size in syngas conversion, offering an effective strategy for optimizing product selectivity in higher alcohols synthesis. coredata.dc:description: The valence state and size of copper species play a critical role in the conversion of syngas to higher alcohols. In this study, CuAl binary catalysts with tunable Cu+-Cu0 ratios and broad size distributions were successfully synthesized by adjusting the heat-treatment pressure of complete liquid-phase method, and their performance in CO hydrogenation was evaluated. The characterization results demonstrated that increasing heat-treatment pressure led to a general increase in both the Cu species size and the Cu⁺/(Cu⁺+Cu0) ratio. Additionally, heat-treated under high pressure significantly enhanced the interaction between the Cu and Al components, promoted the formation of oxygen vacancies on AlOOH, and facilitated electron transfer. Notably, the oxygen vacancy content exhibited a linear correlation with the Cu+/(Cu++Cu0) ratio. The catalytic performance revealed a synergistic effect between the valence state and size of copper species in promoting higher alcohol synthesis. The percentage of C2+OH increased with the rise in Cu+/(Cu++Cu0) ratio and the size of Cu0 and Cu2O. Among the catalysts, C-4 exhibited the largest Cu0 and Cu2O sizes and the highest Cu⁺/(Cu⁺+Cu0) ratio, achieving the highest proportion of higher alcohols (53.52 %). In-situ DRIFTS experiments also confirmed the synergistic effect of both factors. Larger Cu particles facilitated the dissociative adsorption of CO, while Cu⁺ sites favored the non-dissociative adsorption of CO. This work significantly expands the understanding of the role of Cu+-Cu0 ratios and larger copper species in syngas conversion, offering valuable insights for the design of Cu-based catalysts with a high selectivity toward C2+OH.
